qas.question: When following a word such as spill, they are what for most speakers?
If the letter s is a different place in the word, it is typical unaspirated unless the word is what?
If there is a cluster such as st and it belongs to different morphemes, the stop is what?
If the st belongs to one morpheme, then the stop is what?
What is unaspirated since it is not analyzed as three morphemes?
What word-initial is aspirated for almost all speakers?

plausible_answers.text: When the consonants in a cluster like st are analyzed as belonging to different morphemes
because it is analyzed as dis- + taste and the word taste has an aspirated initial t

qas.question: Distaste has an unaspirated middle why?
After a k elsewhere in a word they are normally what?

context: They are <a0_0><a3_0>un<a2_0>aspirated<a3_0/><a2_0/><a0_0/> for almost all speakers when immediately following word-initial <b5_0>s<b5_0/>, as in spill, still, skill. After an s elsewhere in a word they are normally <b8_0>unaspirated<b8_0/> as well, except sometimes in <a1_0>compound words<a1_0/>. <b6_0>When the consonants in a cluster like st are analyzed as belonging to different morphemes<b6_0/> (heteromorphemic) the stop is aspirated, but when they are analyzed as belonging to one morpheme the stop is unaspirated.[citation needed] For instance, <b4_0>distend<b4_0/> has unaspirated [t] since it is not analyzed as two morphemes, but distaste has an aspirated middle [tʰ] <b7_0>because it is analyzed as dis- + taste and the word taste has an aspirated initial t<b7_0/>.
